patient_information: A 62-year-old male Thai police sergeant major from Kalasin Province in northeast Thailand.
chief_complaint: Discovery of a solitary liver mass during an annual physical check-up via abdominal ultrasonography.
history_of_present_illness: Asymptomatic; patient denies any clinical symptoms, weight loss, jaundice, or other gastrointestinal symptoms.
exposure_and_epidemiology: From Kalasin Province in northeast Thailand, an area where eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish (which frequently contains metacercariae of Opisthorchis viverrini) is common. He has a past medical history of liver fluke infection and praziquantel treatment within the last 10 years.
physical_exam: Appears in good health. No jaundice, non-palpable liver and spleen. No liver stigmata or lymphadenopathy detected.
labs_and_diagnostics:
**Imaging:**
- **Abdominal Ultrasonography:** Solitary mass in the liver (initial finding).
- **Abdominal MRI:** Single solid liver mass in the right liver lobe (segments VI/VII), 9x9 cm, without marked bile duct dilatation.

**Laboratory Results (Table 80.1):**
- AST: 26 U/L (Ref: 4–36)
- ALT: 32 U/L (Ref: 12–32)
- ALP: 84 U/L (Ref: 42–121)
- Total bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dL (Ref: 0.3–1.5)
- Direct bilirubin: 0.2 mg/dL (Ref: 0.0–0.5)
- HBsAg (MEIA): Negative
- Anti-HBs (ELISA): 24.13 IU/L (Ref: 0.0–10.0) - suggests previous Hepatitis B infection
- HBeAg (ELISA): Negative
- Anti-HBc (ELISA): Positive (Ref: Negative) - suggests previous Hepatitis B infection
- Anti-HCV: Negative
- AFP: 2.8 U/mL (Ref: 0.0–10.0)
- CEA: 18.96 μg/L (Ref: 0.0–2.5) - elevated
- CA19-9: 342.80 U/mL (Ref: 0.0–37.0) - markedly elevated

**Surgical/Histopathological Findings:**
- **Gross:** Large (9x9 cm), whitish-yellowish tumor in the right liver lobe (segment VII/VIII).
- **Microscopic:** Infiltrative compact glandular structures, lined by dysplastic columnar cells with necrosis, confirming intrahepatic CCA. Liver parenchyma appeared non-cirrhotic. Liver flukes (Opisthorchis viverrini) were detected in the adjacent dilated bile duct.
differential_diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma (CCA), metastatic tumor, and infections (including tuberculosis). Cholangiocarcinoma is considered the most likely diagnosis given the high serum CA19-9 level in an asymptomatic patient without signs of chronic viral hepatitis; metastatic cancer also considered.
management_and_clinical_course: Patient was admitted and underwent hemihepatectomy. Started on postoperative chemotherapy.
final_diagnosis: Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) associated with Opisthorchis viverrini liver fluke infection.
